lesson.name: Lesson 1.2: Writing Equations to Model Relationships, Part 1

page.title: 1.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will begin to learn how to write equations to model various situations. For instance, modeling scenarios with equations can help you figure out how much you need to pay for one pound of blueberries or how much tax you need to pay when buying a meal at a restaurant.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Tell which quantities in a situation can vary and which ones cannot.
  • Use letters and numbers to write equations representing the relationships in a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.2.1: Finding the Percent of 200
  • 1.2.2: Modeling with Equations to Find Edges in Platonic Solids
  • 1.2.2: Self Check 
  • 1.2.3: Writing Equations to Represent Relationships
  • 1.2.3: Self Check 
  • 1.2.4: Writing Equations to Represent Relationships with Percentages
  • 1.2.4: Self Check
  • 1.2.5: Writing Equations to Represent T-Shirts

After that, you‚Äôll practice and review.

  • 1.2.6: Practice
  • 1.2.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.2.1: Finding the Percent of 200
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Evaluate mentally.

  1. \( 25 \)% of \( 200 \)
  2. \( 12 \)% of \( 200 \) 
  3. \( 8 \)% of \( 200 \)
  4. \( p \)% of \( 200 \)

Think about how you came to your answers. To check if you are correct, select the Solutions button here.

Here are the correct answers:

  1. \( 50 \)
  2. \( 24 \)
  3. \( 16 \)
  4. \( \frac{p}{100} \ \cdot200 \), or \( 2p \)

You learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.2.2: Modeling with Equations to Find Edges in Platonic Solids
page.contents:
Activity

These three figures are called Platonic solids.

Tetrahedron

Cube

Dodecahedron

The table shows the number of faces, vertices, and edges for the tetrahedron and dodecahedron.


 faces
vertices
edges
tetrahedron 4 4 6
cube

dodecahedron 12 20 30

1. Complete the missing values for the cube. Then, make at least two observations about the number of faces, edges, and vertices in a Platonic solid.
2. There are some interesting relationships between the number of faces (\( F \)), edges (\( E \)), and vertices (\( V \)) in all Platonic solids. For example, the number of edges is always greater than the number of faces, or \( E > F \). Another example: The number of edges is always less than the sum of the number of faces and the number of vertices, or \( E< F+V \).

There is a relationship that can be expressed with an equation. Can you find it? If so, write an equation to represent it.

Enter your answer here:

  1. The cube has 6 faces, 8 vertices, and 12 edges. Sample observations:
    • The number of edges is greater than both the number of faces and the number of vertices.
    • All the numbers are even numbers.
    • The number of faces is less than or equal to the number of vertices.
  2. The number of edges is 2 less than the sum of the other two numbers. \( V + F ‚àí 2 = E \) (or equivalent)

If you struggled with these questions, remember that practicing making observations makes problems like this feel easier. Keep at it!


There are two more Platonic solids: an octahedron, which has 8 faces that are all triangles, and an icosahedron, which has 20 faces that are all triangles.

  1. How many edges would each of these solids have? (Keep in mind that each edge is used in two faces.)
  2. Use your discoveries from the activity to determine how many vertices each of these solids would have.
  3. For all 5 Platonic solids, determine how many faces meet at each vertex.
Write your answer here:

Check your work:

1. The octahedron has 12 edges. The icosahedron has 30 edges.
2. The octahedron has 6 vertices. The icosahedron has 12 vertices.
3. The tetrahedron, cube, and dodecahedron have 3 faces meeting at each vertex. The octahedron has 4 faces meeting at each vertex. The icosahedron has 5 faces meeting at each vertex.

Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned right before this‚Äî are you using it the right way?

page.title: 1.2.2: Self Check
page.contents: The sum of the measures of the angles of a triangle is \( 180¬∞ \). The right triangle shown has angle measures \( a \), \( b \), and \( 90¬∞ \). Which equation could model this relationship?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Sum means to add. The angles measures must be added. The sum is 180. The answer is \( a+b+90=180 \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Sum means to add. The measures of all three angles must be added. The sum is 180. The answer is \( a+b+90=180 \).
That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: The measures of the angles must be added. The sum is 180. The answer is \( a+b+90=180 \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Sum means to add. The angle measures must be added. The sum is 180. The answer is \( a+b+90=180 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Equations Using Symbols

Here are two more examples of writing statements algebraically using symbols.

Example 1

We want to express the following statement using symbolic language: 
The sum of three consecutive integers is 372.

  • Do the first step, and hold up your whiteboard.
    • Let \( x \) be the first integer.
  • If we let \( x \) represent the first integer, what do we need to do to get the next consecutive integer?
    • If \( x \) is the first integer, we add 1 to \( x \) to get the next integer.
  • In symbols, the next integer would be \( ùë• + 1 \). What do we need to do now to get the next consecutive integer?
    • We need to add 1 to that integer, or \( ùë• + 1+ 1 \); this is the same as \( ùë• +2 \).
  • Now, express the statement: The sum of three consecutive integers is 372.
    • \( ùë• + ùë• +1 + ùë• + 2 = 372 \)

Example 2

We want to express the following statement using symbolic language:
The sum of three consecutive odd integers is 93.

  • Do the first step, and hold up your whiteboard.
    • Let \( x \) be the first odd integer.
  • If we let \( x \) represent the first odd integer, what do we need to do to get the next odd integer?
    • If \( x \) is the first odd integer, we add 2 to \( x \) to get the next odd integer.
  • In symbols, the next odd integer would be \( ùë• + 2 \). What do we need to do now to get the next odd integer?
    • We need to add 2 to that odd integer, or \( ùë• + 2 +2 \); this is the same as \( ùë• + 4 \).
  • Now, express the statement: The sum of three consecutive odd integers is 93.
    • \( ùë• + ùë• +2 + ùë• + 4 = 93 \)
  • Represent the statement ‚ÄúThe sum of three consecutive odd integers is 93‚Äù in another way. Be prepared to explain why both are correct.
    • Answers will vary. Accept any correct answers and justifications. For example, students may write \( ùë• + ùë• + ùë• + 6 = 93 \) and state that it is equivalent to the equation \( ùë• +ùë• +2 + ùë• + 4 = 93 \). Because the associative and commutative properties of addition were applied, those properties do not change the value of an expression.

Try It: Writing Equations Using Symbols

Now it‚Äôs your turn. Write the statement below algebraically using symbols.

The sum of three consecutive integers is 1,623.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to express this statement using symbols.

Steps


Step 1. Read the problem.

The sum of three consecutive integers is 1,623.

Step 2. Identify the variables and known values.

Let \( x \) be the first integer.

\( x, x+1, x+2 \)

Step 3. Translate the sentence into an equation.

\( x+x+1+x+2=1,623 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.2.3: Self Check
page.contents: Max and Jules are renting a car for their 3-day trip. The rental company charges $50 per day and $0.40 per mile driven. Which is a possible equation for their cost of the rental car?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: The cost per mile should represent 40 cents, which is 0.40. The correct answer is \( C=50(3)+0.40m \).

Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: This equation shows they traveled 3 miles. The number of miles is unknown, \( m \), and the cost per mile should be 0.40. The cost per day is $50, and the number of days is known, 3. The correct answer is \( C=50(3)+0.40m \).

Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Look for the known and unknown values. The cost per day is known, $50. The number of days of the trip is known, 3. The number of miles driven is unknown, \( m \). The cost per mile is known, $0.40. The correct answer is \( C=50(3)+0.40m \).
That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: They will pay $50 times 3 days plus 0.40 multiplied by the number of miles, \( C=50(3)+0.40m \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.2.4: Self Check
page.contents: Sweet‚Äôs Candy Store charges $5.00 to fill a bag of candy. There is also a sales tax of 7% per purchase. Mrs. Smith buys 4 bags of candy for her children for Christmas. What is an equation that can represent the cost of the candy that Mrs. Smith buys?

answer.response: That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: Mrs. Smith will pay $5 times 4 bags plus 7% of $5 times 4 bags for the purchase of the candy.
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Be sure to include the original price of the 4 bags of candy at $5.00 a bag. The correct answer is \( C=0.07(4(5))+4(5) \).

Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Be sure to include the tax amount multiplied by the cost of the candy. Then add the tax to the cost of the candy. The correct answer is \( C=0.07(4(5))+4(5) \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: You must multiply the tax rate by the cost of the 4 bags of candy. The correct answer is \( C=0.07(4(5))+4(5) \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.2.3: Writing Equations to Represent Relationships
page.contents:
Activity

1. Write an equation to represent each situation. Enter your answers in the text boxes that follow.

a. Blueberries are $4.99 a pound. Diego buys \( b \) pounds of blueberries and pays $14.95.

Enter your answer here:

Check your work: \( 4.99 ‚ãÖ ùëè = 14.95 \)


b. Blueberries are $4.99 a pound. Jada buys \( p \) pounds of blueberries and pays \( c \) dollars.

Enter your answer here:

Check your work: \( 4.99 ‚ãÖ ùëù = ùëê \)



c. Blueberries are \( d \) dollars a pound. Lin buys \( q \) pounds of blueberries and pays \( t \) dollars.

Enter your answer here:

Check your work: \( ùëë ‚ãÖ ùëû = ùë° \)



d. Noah earned \( n \) dollars over the summer. Mai earned $275, which is $45 more than Noah did.

Enter your answer here:

Check your work: \( n + 45 = 275 \) or \( 275 ‚àí 45 = n  \) (or equivalent)



e. Noah earned \( v \) dollars over the summer. Mai earned \( m \) dollars, which is 45 dollars more than Noah did.

Enter your answer here:

Check your work: \( ùë£ + 45 = ùëö \) or \( ùëö ‚àí 45 = ùë£  \) (or equivalent)



f. Noah earned \( w \) dollars over the summer. Mai earned \( x \) dollars, which is \( y \) dollars more than Noah did.

Enter your answer here:

Check your work: \( ùë§ + ùë¶ = ùë• \) or \( ùë• ‚àí ùë¶ = ùë§ \) (or equivalent)


2. How are the equations you wrote for the blueberry purchases like the equations you wrote for Mai‚Äôs and Noah‚Äôs summer earnings? How are they different?

Enter your answer here:
Check your work:

The two sets of equations are alike in that in each set:
  • Each equation involves three quantities.
  • The first equation has two known quantities, the second has one known quantity, and the last one has no known quantities.
They are different in that:
  • The three quantities in each set are different. In the first set, they are unit price, pounds of blueberries, and total cost. In the second set, they are Noah‚Äôs earnings, Mai‚Äôs earnings, and the difference between the two.
  • In the first set, the relationship involves multiplication. In the second, it involves addition (or subtraction).

page.title: 1.2.4: Writing Equations to Represent Relationships with Percentages
page.contents:
Activity

The tax on the sale of a car in Michigan is 6%. At a dealership in Ann Arbor, a car purchase also involves $120 in miscellaneous charges.

1. There are several quantities in this situation: the original car price, sales tax, miscellaneous charges, and total price. Write an equation to describe the relationship between all the quantities when:
  1. The original car price is $9,500.
  2. The original car price is $14,699.
  3. The total price is $22,480.
  4. The original price is \( p \).

Write your answers here:

Check your work:

  1. \( ùëá = 9,500 + 0.06(9,500) + 120 \), or \( ùëá = 1.06(9,500) + 120 \)
  2. \( ùëá = 14,699 + 0.06(14,699) + 120 \), or \( ùëá = 1.06(14,699) + 120 \)
  3. \( 22,480 = ùëù + 0.06ùëù + 120 \), or \( 22,480 = 1.06ùëù + 120 \)
  4. \( ùëá = ùëù + 0.06ùëù + 120 \), or \( ùëá = 1.06ùëù + 120 \)


2. How would each equation you wrote change if the tax on car sales is \( r \)% and the miscellaneous charges are \( m \) dollars?

Write your answers here:

Check your work:

  1. \( ùëá = 9,500 + \frac{r}{100}(9,500)+m \)
  2. \(ùëá = 14,699 + \frac{r}{100}(14,699)+m\)
  3. \(22,480=p+\frac{r}{100}(p)+m\)
  4. \(T=p+\frac{r}{100}(p)+m\)

Equations equivalent to these are also correct.

page.title: 1.2.5: Writing Equations to Represent T-Shirts
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A school choir needs to make T-shirts for its 75 members and has set aside some money in their budget to pay for them. The members of the choir decided to order from a printing company that charges $3 per shirt, plus a $50 fee for each color to be printed on the shirts.

1. Write an equation that represents the relationship between the number of T-shirts ordered, the number of colors on the shirts, and the total cost of the order. If you use a variable, specify what it represents.

Write your answers here:

Check your work:

\( 75 \cdot 3 + 50ùë• = ùê∑ \) (or equivalent) 

\( ùë• \) represents the number of colors on the shirts. 

\( D \) represents the total cost in dollars.


2. In this situation, which quantities do you think can vary? Which might be fixed?

Write your answers here:

Compare your answer to the sample response: 

The cost per shirt and the fee per color are fixed (they are set by the printing company). The number of colors on the shirts can vary, and so can the total cost, depending on the number of colors being printed.

page.title: 1.2.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Video: Writing an Equation to Represent a Real-World Problem

Watch the following video to learn more about how to write an equation to represent a real-world problem.


Here are the steps to writing an equation to represent a real-world scenario:

Step 1

Read the problem.

Step 2

Identify the variables and known values.

Step 3

Write a sentence using the relationship among the values.

Step 4

Translate the sentence into an equation.

Try It: Writing an Equation to Represent a Real-World Problem


Translate the following scenario into an equation:

A married couple together earns $110,000 a year. The wife earns $16,000 less than twice what her husband earns. What does the husband earn?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to turn this scenario into an equation using the four-step process:

Step 1. Read the problem.


Step 2. Identify the variables and known values.

The husband and wife earn $110,000 a year.

The wife earns $16,000 less than twice what her husband earns.

Let \( h \) = the amount the husband earns.

Step 3. Write a sentence using the relationship among the values.

\( 2h ‚àí 16,000 \) = the amount the wife earns.

Together the husband and wife earn $110,000.

Step 4. Translate the sentence into an equation.

\( h + 2h ‚àí 16,000 = $110,000 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.2.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing an Equation to Represent a Real-World Problem with Percentages

The steps for writing an equation to represent a real-world scenario with percentages are the same as before. Just be sure to change the given percent to a decimal before you use it in the equation.

Step 1

Read the problem.

Step 2

Identify the variables and known values.

Step 3

Write a sentence using the relationship among the values.

Step 4

Translate the sentence into an equation.

For example, what is an equation that can represent this scenario?

The label on Audrey‚Äôs yogurt said that one serving provided 12 grams of protein, which is 24% of the recommended daily amount. What is the total recommended daily amount of protein?

Here‚Äôs how to use the steps:

Step 1. Read the problem.


Step 2. Identify the variables and known values.

Let \( a \) = total amount of protein (in grams).

Step 3. Write a sentence using the relationship among the values.


Step 4. Translate the sentence into an equation.

\( 12 = 0.24a \)

Try It: Writing an Equation to Represent a Real-World Problem with Percentages


What is an equation that can represent this scenario?

One serving of wheat square cereal has 7 grams of fiber, which is 28% of the recommended daily amount. What is the total recommended daily amount of fiber?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here‚Äôs how to write an equation that can represent this scenario:

Step 1. Read the problem.


Step 2. Identify the variables and known values.

Let \( a \) = total amount of fiber (in grams).

Step 3. Write a sentence using the relationship among the values.

\( 7 \) g is 28% of the total amount

Step 4. Translate the sentence into an equation.

\( 7 = 0.28a \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.2.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Translate to an equation: Which equation means nine more than x is equal to 52.
Multiple choice:

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is x + 9 = 52. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. Translate to an equation: Which equation means ten less than m is ‚àí14.

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again?

The correct answer is m ‚àí 10 = ‚àí14. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. Translate to an equation: Which equation means the sum of y and ‚àí30 is 40.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is y + ‚àí30 = 40. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. Translate to an equation: For a family birthday dinner, Celeste bought a turkey that weighed 5 pounds less than the one she bought for Thanksgiving. The birthday turkey weighed 16 pounds. Which equation represents how much the Thanksgiving turkey weighed?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again?

The correct answer is x ‚àí 5 = 16. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. Translate to an equation: Which equation represents 45% of 120?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is x = 0.45(120). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. Translate to an equation: 250% of 65 can also be written as:

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.2.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is x = 2.5(65). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. Translate to an equation: Geneva treated her parents to dinner at their favorite restaurant. The bill was $74.25. Geneva wants to leave 16% of the total bill as a tip. How much should the tip be?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is t = 0.16(74.25). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. Large cheese pizzas cost $5 each, and large one-topping pizzas cost $6 each.
Choose the equation that represents the total cost, T, of c large cheese pizzas and d large one-topping pizzas.

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(T=5c+6d\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. Jada plans to serve milk and healthy cookies for a book club meeting. She is preparing 12 ounces of milk and 4 cookies per person. Including herself, there are 15 people in the club. A package of cookies contains 24 cookies and costs $4.50. A 1-gallon jug of milk contains 128 ounces and costs $3. Let n represent the number of people in the club, m represent the ounces of milk, c represent the number of cookies, and b represent Jada‚Äôs budget in dollars.

Select all of the equations that could represent the quantities and constraints in this situation.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \(m=12(15)\) and \(4n=c\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.2.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Tell which quantities in a situation can vary and which ones cannot.
  • Use letters and numbers to write equations representing the relationships in a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.2.1: Finding the Percent of 200 
    • In this activity, you found different percentages of 200 by changing the percent to a decimal and writing an expression.
  • 1.2.2: Modeling with Equations to Find Edges in Platonic Solids
    • In this activity, you modeled the relationship between the edges, vertices, and faces of Platonic solids with an equation.
  • 1.2.2: Self Check 
  • 1.2.3: Writing Equations to Represent Relationships
    • In this activity, you worked to write more equations that modeled different situations.
  • 1.2.3: Self Check 
  • 1.2.4: Writing Equations to Represent Relationships with Percentages
    • In this activity, you continued to write equations to model given situations but incorporated percentages.
  • 1.2.4: Self Check
  • 1.2.5: Writing Equations to Represent T-Shirts
    • In this activity, you wrote an equation about the cost of T-shirts for a choir group. You also identified which quantities were fixed in the situation and which quantities could change.
After these activities, you completed the following practice:
  • 1.2.6: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you‚Äôve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
